bestBHT.bht: The chief priests, in their efforts to condemn Jesus, shamefully proclaimed, We have no king but Caesar. By rejecting Christ, they deprived themselves of grace and blessings, succumbing to endless miseries. Their cry of Away with him! served their immediate purpose of crucifying Jesus, but ultimately led to their downfall. This display of madness left them devoid of power and government, confessing the departure of authority from Judah.

Henry Alford: We have no king but Caesar, was a degrading confession from the chief priests of that people of whom it was said, ‘The Lord your God is your King.'
They were so earnest in repudiating Jesus," says Bengel, "that they repudiate their Messiah altogether.
The cry furthered the present purpose, and to this all was sacrificed, including truth itself; for the confession was not only degrading, but false in their mouths.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Some of those who thus cried died miserably in rebellion against Cæsar forty years afterwards.
But it suited their present purpose.
Marvin Vincent: These chief representatives of the theocratic government of Israel thus formally and expressly renounce it, and declare their allegiance to a temporal and pagan power. This utterance is 'the formal abdication of the Messianic hope.'" (Commentary on John 19:15)
The pronoun of remote reference isolates and sharply distinguishes them from Jesus. See on 13 27." (Commentary on John 19:15)
John Calvin: This is a display of shocking madness, that the priests, who ought to have been well acquainted with the Law, reject Christ, in whom the salvation of the people was wholly contained, on whom all the promises depended, and on whom the whole of their religion was founded; and, indeed, by rejecting Christ, they deprive themselves of the grace of God and of every blessing.
We see, then, what insanity had seized them... Thus wicked men, in order to fly from Christ, not only deprive themselves of eternal life, but draw down on their heads every kind of miseries.

On the other hand, the sole happiness of the godly is, to be subject to the royal authority of Christ, whether, according to the flesh, they are placed under a just and lawful government, under the oppression of tyrants.
Philip Schaff: They therefore cried out, Away with him, away with him, crucify him. Instinct tells them that the last moment when they may accomplish their object is arrived."
Pilate saith unto them, Shall I crucify your King? Then follow those words evidently so full of meaning to the Evangelist."

‘We have no king but Cæsar.’ God is rejected; Messianic hope is trampled under foot. In the moment of securing the death of their true King, ‘the Jews,’ by the mouth of their leaders and representatives, plunge themselves into the lowest depths of guilt and shame.
Archibald T. Robertson: Away with him, away with him. This thing has gotten on the nerves of the crowd."
Pilate weakly repeats his sarcasm: 'Your king shall I crucify?'"
The chief priests were Sadducees, who had no Messianic hope like that of the Pharisees. So to carry their point against Jesus they renounce the principle of the theocracy that God was their King.
John Gill: They rejected the government of the King Messiah, and tacitly confessed that the sceptre was departed from Judah.
They could name no one as king but Jesus, or Caesar; the former they rejected, and were obliged to own the latter.
After the crucifixion of him, all power was taken from them; the government was seized upon by the Romans entirely, and at last utterly destroyed.

bhtAttempts.bht: The chief priests, in their desperate efforts to condemn Jesus, shamefully proclaimed, We have no king but Caesar. In doing so, they not only degraded themselves and renounced their Messiah, but also denied their theocratic government and allegiance to God. This rejection of Christ brought about their ultimate downfall, as many of these very priests perished in the rebellion against Caesar years later. However, their treacherous cry of Away with him! seemed to serve their immediate purpose, leading to the crucifixion of Jesus. This shocking display of madness and rejection of the source of salvation left them devoid of God's grace and subjected to endless miseries. Ultimately, they found themselves stripped of power and the government, having unwittingly confessed that the sceptre had departed from Judah.

The chief priests shamefully proclaimed, We have no king but Caesar, thus rejecting Jesus and renouncing their Messiah. Their cry of Away with him! furthered their immediate purpose of crucifying Jesus, but resulted in their ultimate downfall. This display of madness led to the deprivation of God's grace and the loss of every blessing for these wicked individuals. Ultimately, they found themselves deprived of power and government, having unknowingly confessed the departure of authority from Judah.

The chief priests, in their efforts to condemn Jesus, shamefully proclaimed, We have no king but Caesar. By rejecting Christ, they deprived themselves of grace and blessings, succumbing to endless miseries. Their cry of Away with him! served their immediate purpose of crucifying Jesus, but ultimately led to their downfall. This display of madness left them devoid of power and government, confessing the departure of authority from Judah.

The chief priests, in their zealous denial of Jesus and rejection of their Messiah, degradingly confessed, We have no king but Caesar. Their desperate cries of Away with him! not only advanced their immediate agenda but also led to their eventual ruin. This shocking display of madness resulted in the loss of God's grace and blessings for these wicked individuals. Their rejection of Christ caused them to forfeit eternal life and subject themselves to endless miseries. In the end, their renunciation of Jesus and allegiance to Caesar left them powerless and confirmed that the authority had departed from Judah.

The chief priests shamefully confessed, We have no king but Caesar, forsaking their hope in the Messianic salvation. Their cry of Away with him! fulfilled their immediate purpose, but led to their own downfall. By rejecting Jesus, they deprived themselves of God's grace and subjected themselves to unimaginable miseries. This rejection of the King Messiah stripped them of power, leaving them under the authority of Caesar. Their actions demonstrated a shocking display of madness and a rejection of their own religion's foundation.
